definition: Authentication, Authorization, and Accounting (AAA) is a framework for intelligently controlling access to computer resources, enforcing policies, auditing usage, and providing the information necessary to bill for services. These combined processes are considered a single security function that is shared across many network devices (NIST IR 7298 Rev. 3).

After Action Report (AAR) – A summary document produced after an incident response, detailing what happened, how it was handled, lessons learned, and recommendations for improvement (NIST SP 800-61 Rev. 2).
Attribute-Based Access Control (ABAC) – A logical access control model that uses attributes (e.g., user role, object type, time of day) to make dynamic access decisions (NIST SP 800-162).
Access control is limiting access to information to authorized users, programs, or other systems (ISO/IEC 27000:2022).

Access Control List (ACL) – A list or register containing access control attributes that specifies, for a given system resource, which subjects are granted access to that resource and what operations are allowed on it (NIST IR 7298 Rev. 3).
Access Pattern Analysis – Monitoring and analyzing patterns of access to detect anomalies that may indicate unauthorized activity (SANS Glossary).
Access Token – A credential used to access protected resources in OAuth 2.0, representing an authorization issued to the client by the authorization server (RFC 6749).
Account Harvesting – The process of collecting usernames and passwords from compromised systems or phishing campaigns for later use in attacks (OWASP Cheat Sheet Series).
Account Lockout – A security measure that disables an account after a specified number of unsuccessful authentication attempts to prevent brute force attacks (NIST SP 800-63B).
Account Takeover (ATO) – A security incident where an unauthorized user gains control of a legitimate user’s account, often through credential stuffing or phishing (OWASP Top 10).
Active Attack – An attack that attempts to alter system resources or affect their operation (NIST IR 7298 Rev. 3).

Active Directory (AD) – A directory service developed by Microsoft for Windows domain networks that provides a centralized database for user authentication and authorization (Microsoft Documentation, referenced in NIST SP 800-53).
Active Scanning – The process of sending probes to a system or network to discover vulnerabilities or gather information (NIST SP 800-115).
Address Resolution Protocol (ARP) – A protocol used to map an IP address to a physical machine address (MAC address) on a local network (RFC 826).

Address Resolution Protocol Spoofing – A type of attack in which an attacker sends forged ARP messages to associate the attacker's MAC address with the IP address of another host, enabling man-in-the-middle attacks (MITRE ATT&CK T1557).
Adversary Emulation – The process of simulating an adversary’s tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) to test defensive capabilities (MITRE ATT&CK).
Adware – Software that automatically displays or downloads advertising material (sometimes for a fee to the provider) when a user is online (NIST IR 7298 Rev. 3).

Advanced Encryption Standard (AES) – A symmetric block cipher approved by the U.S. National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) in FIPS PUB 197, which supersedes the Data Encryption Standard (DES) (NIST IR 7298 Rev. 3).

Advanced Persistent Threat (APT) – An adversary that possesses sophisticated levels of expertise and significant resources that allow it to create opportunities to achieve its objectives by using multiple attack vectors (e.g., cyber, physical, or deception) (NIST SP 800-39).
Air-Gapped Network – A network that is physically isolated from other networks, including the Internet, to prevent unauthorized access (NIST SP 800-53).
Alert Fatigue – A condition where security personnel become desensitized to alerts due to the high volume of notifications, leading to reduced response effectiveness (SANS Glossary).
Allowlist – A list of entities that are permitted by default, opposite to a blocklist (NIST SP 800-179).
Anomaly Detection – The process of identifying deviations from normal behavior in a system or network, often indicating potential security incidents (NIST SP 800-94).
Anti-Forensic Technique – Methods or tools used to frustrate or impede forensic investigations, such as data wiping, encryption, or log tampering (NIST SP 800-86).
Antimalware – Software designed to detect, prevent, and remove malicious software (malware) from a system (NIST SP 800-83).
Application Allowlisting – A security control that permits only approved applications to execute on a system, preventing unauthorized or malicious software from running (NIST SP 800-167).
Application Layer – The top layer (Layer 7) of the OSI reference model, which provides services to application processes (ISO/IEC 7498-1).
Application Security – The use of software, hardware, and procedural methods to protect applications from external threats (OWASP).
Artifact – An object or item created or modified by a subject's activity that may contain evidentiary value in a forensic investigation (NIST SP 800-86).
Asset – Anything that has value to an organization, including information, systems, and physical items (ISO/IEC 27000:2022).
Asset Management – The process of identifying, classifying, and controlling assets to ensure their security throughout their lifecycle (ISO/IEC 27001).
Asymmetric Cryptography – A cryptographic system using public and private keys where the public key is used for encryption and the private key for decryption (NIST SP 800-57).
Attack Chain – The sequence of stages in a cyber attack, from reconnaissance to exfiltration, often modeled by frameworks like the Cyber Kill Chain (MITRE ATT&CK).
Attack Surface – The sum of all points on the boundary of a system where an unauthorized user can try to enter data to or extract data from the system (OWASP).
Attack Tree – A hierarchical representation of the logical relationships between possible attack paths to a system or asset (NIST SP 800-30).
Audit Log – A chronological record of system activities, including user actions, that can be used to trace security-relevant events (ISO/IEC 27001).
Audit Trail – A set of records that collectively provide documentary evidence of an action, procedure, or event, often used for accountability and non-repudiation (NIST IR 7298 Rev. 3).
Authentication – The process of verifying the identity of a user, device, or other entity (NIST SP 800-63B).

Authentication Factor – One of three categories of something you know (e.g., password), something you have (e.g., token), or something you are (e.g., biometric) used to verify identity (NIST SP 800-63B).
Authorization – The process of granting or denying access to a resource based on a verified identity (ISO/IEC 27000:2022).
Automated Threat – Attacks carried out by bots or automated scripts, such as credential stuffing or DDoS (OWASP).
Backdoor – A method of bypassing normal authentication or encryption in a system, often left by developers or inserted by attackers (NIST SP 800-82).
Backup – A copy of data or files created for the purpose of recovery in case of loss or corruption (NIST SP 800-53).
Banner Grabbing – A technique used to gain information about a remote computer, such as the operating system and version of software it is running, by querying service banners (OWASP).
Baseline Configuration – A documented set of specifications for an information system that is used as a basis for change control and security assessments (NIST SP 800-128).
Bastion Host – A strongly protected system that serves as a gateway between a trusted internal network and an untrusted external network (NIST SP 800-41).
Behavioral Analysis – The examination of patterns of user or system behavior to detect anomalies that may indicate compromise (SANS Glossary).
Behavioral Biometrics – Authentication based on unique behavioral patterns, such as typing rhythm or mouse movements (NIST SP 800-63B).
Biometric Authentication – The use of unique physical or behavioral characteristics (e.g., fingerprints, iris scans) to verify identity (NIST SP 800-63B).
Bit Flipping – An attack that alters specific bits in encrypted data to change its meaning, often in cryptographic protocols (MITRE ATT&CK).
BitLocker – A full disk encryption feature included in some versions of Microsoft Windows that uses the Advanced Encryption Standard (AES) algorithm (NIST SP 800-111).
Black Hat – An individual who performs unauthorized and malicious actions, often for personal gain or harm (SANS Glossary).
Blockchain – A distributed ledger technology that allows for secure, transparent, and immutable recording of transactions across multiple computers (NIST IR 8202).
Block Cipher – A cryptographic algorithm that operates on fixed-length blocks of data, such as AES (NIST SP 800-57).
Blocklist – A list of entities that are denied by default, opposite to an allowlist (NIST SP 800-179).
Blue Team – The group that defends against cyber attacks, focusing on detection, response, and recovery (SANS Glossary).
Bootkit – A type of malware that infects the boot process of a system, allowing it to load before the operating system (SANS).
Boot Record – The sector of a storage device that contains the code to start the operating system (NIST SP 800-86).
Bot – A compromised device that is remotely controlled by an attacker, often part of a botnet (NIST SP 800-83).
Botnet – A network of compromised devices controlled by an external source, used for coordinated attacks like DDoS (NIST SP 800-83).
Botmaster – The individual or group that controls a botnet (NIST SP 800-83).
Boundary Defense – Security measures implemented at the perimeter of a network to protect internal resources (SANS Glossary).
Breach – The confirmed occurrence of unauthorized access to or disclosure of data (NIST SP 800-53).
Bring Your Own Device (BYOD) – A policy allowing employees to use personal devices for work purposes, requiring specific security controls (NIST SP 800-124).
Brute Force Attack – An attack that attempts to guess credentials or keys by trying all possible combinations systematically (OWASP).
Buffer Overflow – A condition where a program attempts to write more data to a buffer than it can hold, potentially leading to arbitrary code execution (CWE-120).
Business Continuity Plan (BCP) – A plan for maintaining or resuming business functions during and after a disruption (ISO/IEC 22301).
Business Email Compromise (BEC) – A type of targeted fraud where attackers impersonate executives to trick employees into transferring funds (FBI).
Cache Poisoning – An attack that injects false information into a cache, such as DNS cache, to redirect traffic (RFC 1035).
Canary Token – A decoy object designed to detect unauthorized access by triggering an alert when interacted with (Thinkst Canary).
Carving – The process of extracting files from unallocated space or raw data without relying on file system metadata (NIST SP 800-86).
Certificate Authority (CA) – An entity that issues digital certificates, verifying the identity of the certificate holder (RFC 5280).
Certificate Revocation List (CRL) – A list of certificates that have been revoked before their expiration date (RFC 5280).
Chain of Custody – The chronological documentation or paper trail that records the seizure, custody, control, transfer, analysis, and disposition of physical or electronic evidence (NIST SP 800-86).
Challenge-Handshake Authentication Protocol (CHAP) – An authentication protocol for PPP that avoids sending passwords in cleartext (RFC 1994).
Chief Information Security Officer (CISO) – The executive responsible for overseeing an organization's information security program (ISO/IEC 27001).
Child Exploitation Material (CEM) – Digital media depicting the sexual abuse of minors, subject to strict forensic handling (SWGDE).
Ciphertext – Data that has been encrypted, rendering it unreadable without the proper decryption key (NIST SP 800-111).
Clickjacking – A malicious technique for tricking a user into clicking on something different from what the user perceives they are clicking on (OWASP).
Cloud Access Security Broker (CASB) – A tool that acts as a gatekeeper between users and cloud services to enforce security policies (Gartner).
Cloud Security – The set of policies, technologies, and controls to protect cloud-based systems, data, and infrastructure (NIST SP 800-144).
Code Injection – The technique of inserting malicious code into an application to execute unintended commands (OWASP).
Code Signing – The process of digitally signing executables and scripts to confirm the author and guarantee that the code has not been altered (Microsoft).
Cold Boot Attack – A type of attack that exploits the volatility of RAM by cooling it to preserve data after power-off for extraction (SANS).
Command and Control (C2) – The means by which attackers maintain communication with and control over compromised systems (MITRE ATT&CK).
Common Criteria – An international standard (ISO/IEC 15408) for computer security certification of evaluated products (NIST IR 7298 Rev. 3).
Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVE) – A dictionary of common names (e.g., CVE-XXXX-YYYY) for publicly known cybersecurity vulnerabilities (MITRE).
Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) – A standard for assessing the severity of vulnerabilities based on exploitability and impact (FIRST).
Compliance – The adherence to laws, regulations, standards, and policies relevant to information security (ISO/IEC 27001).
Computational Forensics – The use of computational methods to analyze digital evidence, often involving AI and pattern recognition (SWGDE).
Computer Emergency Response Team (CERT) – An expert group that handles computer security incidents (NIST SP 800-61).
Computer Security Incident Response Team (CSIRT) – A service organization that is responsible for receiving, reviewing, and otherwise responding to computer security incident reports (ENISA).
Confidentiality – Ensuring that information is accessible only to those authorized to have access (ISO/IEC 27000:2022).

column4: Confidentiality, Integrity, Availability (CIA Triad) – The three key principles of information security that guide policy and control implementation (ISO/IEC 27000:2022).

definition: Configuration Management – The process of identifying, controlling, and tracking changes to system configurations to maintain security (NIST SP 800-128).
Container – A lightweight, standalone, executable package that includes everything needed to run a piece of software, including code, runtime, and dependencies (Docker).
Container Escape – A technique where an attacker breaks out of a container to gain access to the host system (MITRE ATT&CK T1611).
Content Delivery Network (CDN) – A system of distributed servers that deliver web content based on user location to reduce latency (RFC 6984).
Continuous Monitoring – The process of collecting, analyzing, and reporting on security-related information in an ongoing manner (NIST SP 800-137).
Cookie – A piece of data sent by a web server to a browser, which the browser stores and sends back on subsequent requests to the same server (RFC 6265).
Covert Channel – A communications channel that allows two parties to exchange information in a manner that is not intended by the system's designers (NIST SP 800-53).
Credential Access – The adversary tactic of obtaining credentials to access systems or resources (MITRE ATT&CK TA0006).
Credential Dumping – The technique of extracting credentials from a system's memory or files, such as LSASS process (MITRE ATT&CK T1003).
Credential Stuffing – An attack using stolen username/password pairs to gain unauthorized access to user accounts (OWASP).
Crimeware – Malware designed specifically for criminal purposes, such as ransomware or banking trojans (NIST).
Critical Infrastructure – Systems and assets, whether physical or virtual, so vital that their incapacitation or destruction would have a debilitating impact on national security (NIST).
Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) – An attack that forces an end user to execute unwanted actions on a web application in which they are currently authenticated (OWASP).
Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) – A vulnerability that allows attackers to inject malicious scripts into content from otherwise trusted websites (OWASP).
Cryptanalysis – The analysis of cryptographic systems to find weaknesses or break them without the key (NIST SP 800-57).
Cryptojacking – The unauthorized use of another person's computer to mine cryptocurrency (NIST).
Cryptographic Hash Function – A function that maps data of arbitrary size to a fixed-size value, with properties ensuring collision resistance and pre-image resistance (FIPS 180-4).

Cryptography – The discipline that embodies the principles, means, and methods for the transformation of data to hide its semantic content, protect its integrity or prove its authenticity (NIST SP 800-175B).
Cryptoshredding – The destruction of encryption keys to render encrypted data unrecoverable, effectively erasing it (NIST SP 800-88).

Cyber Kill Chain – A model describing the stages of a cyber attack: reconnaissance, weaponization, delivery, exploitation, installation, command and control, and actions on objectives (Lockheed Martin, referenced in MITRE ATT&CK).

Cyber Threat Intelligence (CTI) – Evidence-based knowledge, including context, mechanisms, indicators, implications, and actionable advice about an existing or emerging threat to assets (NIST SP 800-150).
Cybercalifrage – The technique of hiding malicious activity in plain sight by mimicking legitimate behavior (SANS).
Data Breach – The unauthorized acquisition, access, use, or disclosure of sensitive data (NIST SP 800-53).
Data Center – A facility used to house computer systems and associated components, such as telecommunications and storage systems (NIST).
Data Classification – The process of organizing data into categories based on sensitivity for purposes of applying security controls (NIST SP 800-60).
Data Diode – A hardware device that enforces unidirectional data flow to prevent data leakage (NIST).
Data Exfiltration – The unauthorized transfer of data from a system outside the network perimeter (MITRE ATT&CK TA0010).
Data Integrity – The property that data has not been altered in an unauthorized manner (ISO/IEC 27000:2022).
Data Leakage – The intentional or unintentional release of data from within an organization to an external destination (NIST SP 800-53).
Data Loss Prevention (DLP) – Technologies and processes to detect and prevent unauthorized use or transmission of sensitive data (NIST SP 800-53).
Data Masking – The process of obscuring sensitive data by replacing it with realistic but fictional data (NIST).
Data Minimization – The principle of collecting and retaining only the data necessary for the specified purpose (GDPR, referenced in ISO/IEC 27018).
Data Obfuscation – Techniques to hide or disguise the meaning of data to prevent unauthorized access (NIST).
Data Protection – The process of safeguarding important data from corruption, compromise, or loss (ISO/IEC 27018).
Data Retention – Policies specifying how long data must be kept and when it can be deleted (NIST SP 800-53).
Data Sanitization – The process of deliberately, permanently, and irreversibly removing or destroying data from media (NIST SP 800-88).
Data Spillage – The transfer of classified or sensitive information to an information system that does not have the appropriate security controls (NIST).
Data Sovereignty – The concept that data is subject to the laws and governance of the nation in which it is collected (NIST).
Data Steganography – The practice of concealing a file, message, or image within another file, message, or image (NIST).
Data Warehouse – A repository of integrated data from multiple sources, used for reporting and analysis (NIST).
Database Forensics – The application of forensic techniques to database systems to recover and analyze data (NIST SP 800-86).
Dead Box Forensics – Forensic analysis performed on a powered-off device, focusing on static data (NIST SP 800-86).
Decentralized Identifier (DID) – A new type of identifier that enables verifiable, decentralized digital identity (W3C).
Decoy – A system or data set designed to lure attackers away from real assets or to detect intrusions (NIST SP 800-83).
Decryption – The reversal of the encryption process to convert ciphertext back to plaintext (NIST SP 800-111).
Defense in Depth – The practice of layering multiple security controls to protect assets, ensuring that if one fails, others remain (NSA/NIST).
Demilitarized Zone (DMZ) – A network zone that sits between an organization's internal network and an external network, hosting public-facing services (NIST SP 800-41).
Denial of Service (DoS) – An action that impairs the authorized use of networks, systems, or applications (NIST SP 800-61).
Deny All – A default security policy that blocks all access unless explicitly permitted (NIST SP 800-41).
Deprecation – The discouragement of use of a feature or technology in favor of newer alternatives (NIST).
Detection Engineering – The practice of designing, developing, and maintaining detection rules to identify threats (SANS).
Diameter – A protocol for authentication, authorization, and accounting (AAA) in modern networks, successor to RADIUS (RFC 6733).
Dictionary Attack – A type of brute force attack using a predefined list of words or phrases (OWASP).
Differential Privacy – A mathematical technique for providing privacy guarantees when releasing statistical data (NIST).
Digital Evidence – Information and data of investigative value that is stored or transmitted in digital form (SWGDE).
Digital Forensics – The process of collecting, preserving, analyzing, and presenting digital evidence in a manner that is legally admissible (NIST SP 800-86).
Digital Rights Management (DRM) – Technologies that control the use of digital content after sale (NIST).
Digital Signature – Data appended to a message to provide assurance of origin and integrity (FIPS 186-5).
Digital Signature Algorithm (DSA) – A public-key algorithm for generating and verifying digital signatures (FIPS 186).
Digital Watermarking – Embedding information in digital media to assert ownership or integrity (NIST).
Directory Services – Systems that store and organize information about users and resources for authentication (NIST).
Directory Traversal – A vulnerability allowing access to files outside the intended directory (OWASP).
Disaster Recovery Plan (DRP) – A plan for restoring IT operations after a disaster (NIST SP 800-34).
Discretionary Access Control (DAC) – Access control where the owner of a resource determines who can access it (NIST SP 800-53).
Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) – A DoS attack using multiple compromised systems to flood a target (NIST SP 800-61).
DNS Amplification – A DDoS attack exploiting DNS queries to generate large responses from small requests (US-CERT).
DNS Hijacking – Redirecting DNS queries to malicious servers to control traffic (MITRE ATT&CK).
DNS Security Extensions (DNSSEC) – A suite of extensions to DNS adding security through authentication (RFC 4033).
DNS Tunneling – Encapsulating non-DNS traffic in DNS queries to bypass firewalls (MITRE ATT&CK T1071.004).
Domain Generation Algorithm (DGA) – An algorithm used by malware to generate domain names for command and control (SANS).
Domain Name System (DNS) – A hierarchical and decentralized naming system for computers on the Internet (RFC 1035).
Drive-by Download – Malware downloaded automatically when visiting a compromised website (OWASP).
Drive Imaging – Creating a bit-for-bit copy of a storage device for forensic analysis (NIST SP 800-86).
Dumpster Diving – Searching through trash for discarded sensitive information (SANS).
Dynamic Analysis – The examination of malware by executing it in a controlled environment to observe behavior (SANS).
Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) – A protocol for assigning IP addresses dynamically (RFC 2131).
E-Discovery – The process of identifying, collecting, and producing electronically stored information for legal proceedings (FRCP).
Eavesdropping – The unauthorized interception of communications (RFC 4949).
Edge Computing – Processing data near the source to reduce latency and bandwidth use (NIST).
Electronic Code Book (ECB) – A block cipher mode where each block is encrypted independently (NIST SP 800-57).
Elliptic Curve Cryptography (ECC) – A form of public-key cryptography based on elliptic curves (NIST SP 800-56A).
Encapsulating Security Payload (ESP) – An IPsec protocol providing confidentiality, integrity, and authentication (RFC 4303).
Encryption – The cryptographic transformation of data (plaintext) to produce ciphertext (NIST SP 800-111).
Endpoint Detection and Response (EDR) – Tools for monitoring endpoints to detect and respond to threats (Gartner).
Endpoint Privilege Management – Controlling privileged access on endpoints to minimize risk (NIST SP 800-53).
Endpoint Security – Protection of devices like laptops and mobiles from threats (NIST).
Evil Twin – A rogue Wi-Fi access point mimicking a legitimate one to steal data (OWASP).
Exfiltration Over C2 Channel – Transferring stolen data using command and control infrastructure (MITRE ATT&CK T1041).
Exploit – A piece of software, data, or sequence of commands that takes advantage of a vulnerability (MITRE ATT&CK).
Exploit Kit – A toolkit for automating the delivery and exploitation of vulnerabilities (SANS).
Extended Access Control List (EACL) – An ACL that includes source/destination IP, protocol, and port details (Cisco).
Extended Detection and Response (XDR) – An integrated platform combining data from multiple sources for threat detection (Gartner).
Extended Validation Certificate (EV SSL) – A certificate requiring rigorous verification of the applicant's identity (CA/Browser Forum).
Extensible Authentication Protocol (EAP) – A framework for authentication in wireless networks (RFC 3748).
Fail-Safe – A design feature that automatically puts a system into a safe state upon failure (NIST SP 800-53).
Fail2ban – An intrusion prevention tool that bans IPs after repeated failed login attempts (Open Source).
False Positive – An alert indicating a potential threat when no actual threat exists (NIST SP 800-94).
False Negative – A failure to detect an actual threat or vulnerability (NIST SP 800-94).
Federated Identity – A system where a user's identity is shared across multiple organizations (NIST SP 800-63C).
Federation – The establishment of trust relationships between identity providers (SAML).
File Allocation Table (FAT) – A file system used by older Windows versions for organizing files on disks (NIST).
File Carving – Recovering files from digital media without using file system metadata (NIST SP 800-86).
File Integrity Monitoring (FIM) – Continuous surveillance of files to detect changes (NIST SP 800-53).
File Slack – The unused portion of the last allocated cluster for a file, which may contain residual data (NIST SP 800-86).
File System Forensics – The analysis of file system structures to recover data and metadata (Carrier's File System Forensic Analysis).
Fileless Malware – Malicious code that operates in memory without writing files to disk (SANS).
Firewall – A network device that monitors and controls incoming and outgoing traffic based on security rules (NIST SP 800-41).
Firmware – Software embedded in hardware devices to control their operation (NIST).
Forensic Bridge – A hardware device used as a write-blocker in forensic acquisitions (NIST).
Forensic Copy – An exact duplicate of digital evidence, preserving all data (NIST SP 800-86).
Forensic Duplication – The process of creating multiple copies of evidence for analysis while maintaining integrity (SWGDE).
Forensic Hash – A cryptographic hash used to verify the integrity of forensic images (NIST SP 800-86).
Forensic Image – A bit-for-bit copy of a storage device used as evidence (NIST SP 800-86).
Forensic Toolkit (FTK) – Commercial software for digital forensic investigations (AccessData).
Forensically Sound – A method or process that ensures evidence is not altered and is admissible in court (NIST SP 800-86).
Format String Attack – An attack exploiting poor input validation in format functions to read or write memory (CWE-134).
Forward Secrecy – A property ensuring that session keys are not compromised if long-term keys are (NIST SP 800-57).
Full Disk Encryption (FDE) – Encryption of an entire disk drive, protecting data at rest (NIST SP 800-111).
Fuzzing – Automated software testing technique using invalid or random data as inputs to find vulnerabilities (OWASP).
Gateway – A network node that connects two different networks, often performing protocol translation (NIST).
General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) – EU regulation on data protection and privacy for individuals (EU 2016/679).
Geofencing – Location-based monitoring using GPS to define virtual boundaries (NIST).
Golden Ticket – A forged Kerberos ticket granting unlimited access in Active Directory (MITRE ATT&CK T1558.001).
Governance – The framework of rules, practices, and processes by which an organization ensures accountability (ISO/IEC 27001).
Gray Hat – A hacker who operates between white hat and black hat, often disclosing vulnerabilities for reward (SANS).
Group Policy – A feature of Windows Active Directory for enforcing settings on users and computers (Microsoft).
Guideline – A recommended course of action for using a control (ISO/IEC 27002).
Hard Disk Encryption – Encrypting data on a hard drive to protect against unauthorized access (NIST SP 800-111).
Hardening – The process of securing a system by reducing its attack surface (NIST SP 800-123).
Hash Catastrophe – A situation where a hash collision allows attackers to forge data (NIST).
Hash Value – The output of a hash function, used to verify data integrity (FIPS 180-4).
Hashcat – An advanced password recovery utility supporting various hash types (Hashcat).
Header Manipulation – Altering protocol headers to bypass security controls (MITRE ATT&CK).

term: Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA)
definition: Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) – US law protecting health information privacy (US).
High Availability – System design ensuring continuous operation with minimal downtime (NIST).
Honeynet – A network of honeypots used to attract and study attackers (NIST SP 800-83).
Honeypot – A decoy system designed to detect unauthorized access by attracting attackers (NIST SP 800-83).
Host-Based Intrusion Detection System (HIDS) – A system monitoring a single host for malicious activity (NIST SP 800-94).
Host-Based Intrusion Prevention System (HIPS) – A HIDS that can also block detected threats (NIST SP 800-94).
Host File – A local file overriding DNS resolution for specific domains (NIST).
Hot Swapping – Replacing components without shutting down the system (NIST).
Hybrid Cloud – A cloud infrastructure combining private and public clouds (NIST SP 800-146).
Hypervisor – Software, firmware, or hardware that creates and runs virtual machines (NIST SP 800-125).
Identity and Access Management (IAM) – The framework for managing digital identities and their access to resources (NIST SP 800-63).
Identity Provider (IdP) – A system that creates, maintains, and manages identity information (SAML).
Identity Theft – The fraudulent use of another's identity for gain (NIST).
IEEE 802.1X – A standard for port-based network access control (IEEE).
Image Forensics – The analysis of digital images to determine authenticity or alterations (SWGDE).
Impersonation – Pretending to be another entity to gain unauthorized access (MITRE ATT&CK).
Incident – An occurrence that actually or imminently jeopardizes the confidentiality, integrity, or availability of an information system (NIST SP 800-61).
Incident Handler – An individual who identifies, analyzes, and responds to security incidents (NIST SP 800-61).
Incident Response – The structured approach to handling security breaches or incidents (NIST SP 800-61).
Incident Response Plan (IRP) – A documented set of instructions to detect, respond to, and recover from incidents (NIST SP 800-61).
Indicator of Compromise (IOC) – A forensic artifact or observable that indicates potential malicious activity (MITRE).
Indicator of Exposure (IOE) – An indicator suggesting a vulnerability that could be exploited (MITRE).
Industrial Control System (ICS) – Hardware and software for controlling industrial processes (NIST SP 800-82).
Information Assurance – Measures that protect and defend information and information systems (CNSSI 4009).
Information Leak – The exposure of sensitive information due to misconfiguration or error (NIST).
Information Rights Management (IRM) – Technologies controlling access to sensitive documents (Microsoft).
Information Security – Preservation of confidentiality, integrity, and availability of information (ISO/IEC 27000:2022).
Information Security Management System (ISMS) – A systematic approach to managing sensitive company information so that it remains secure (ISO/IEC 27001).
Information Sharing – The exchange of threat intelligence between organizations (NIST SP 800-150).
Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) – A cloud computing model providing virtualized computing resources (NIST SP 800-146).
Injection Attack – The insertion of malicious code into an application to execute unintended commands (OWASP).
Insider Threat – A threat originating from within an organization, such as an employee (NIST SP 800-53).
Integrity – The property of safeguarding the accuracy and completeness of assets (ISO/IEC 27000:2022).
Integrity Check Value (ICV) – A value computed from a message to verify its integrity (NIST).
Intelligent Transportation System (ITS) – Systems applying advanced technologies to transportation (NIST).
Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) – A supporting protocol for IP used for diagnostics (RFC 792).
Internet of Things (IoT) – A paradigm for uniquely identifiable objects and their virtual representations in an Internet-like structure (NIST IR 8228).
Intrusion – The unauthorized access, use, or modification of a system (NIST SP 800-61).
Intrusion Detection System (IDS) – Software or hardware that detects malicious activity (NIST SP 800-94).
Intrusion Prevention System (IPS) – A system that detects and blocks intrusions in real-time (NIST SP 800-94).
IP Address Spoofing – Forging the source IP address in packets to impersonate another system (RFC 2827).
IPsec – A suite of protocols for securing IP communications by authenticating and encrypting packets (RFC 4301).
IPv6 – The sixth version of the Internet Protocol, providing larger address space (RFC 8200).
ISO/IEC 27001 – The international standard for establishing, implementing, maintaining, and continually improving an ISMS (ISO/IEC 27001:2022).
ISO/IEC 27002 – A code of practice providing guidelines for information security controls (ISO/IEC 27002:2022).
ISO/IEC 27005 – Guidelines for information security risk management (ISO).
JavaScript Object Notation (JSON) – A lightweight data-interchange format (RFC 8259).
John the Ripper – An open-source password cracking tool (Open Source).
Kerberos – A network authentication protocol using secret-key cryptography (RFC 4120).
Kerberoasting – An attack requesting Kerberos tickets for service accounts to crack offline (MITRE ATT&CK T1558.003).
Key Exchange – The process of agreeing on a shared secret key securely (NIST SP 800-56A).
Key Escrow – A process where a third party holds a copy of a private key for recovery (NIST).
Keylogger – A tool that captures keystrokes to steal sensitive information (NIST).
Key Management – The processes for generating, distributing, storing, and destroying cryptographic keys (NIST SP 800-57).
Key Performance Indicator (KPI) – A measurable value demonstrating how effectively security objectives are achieved (ISO/IEC 27004).
Keystroke Dynamics – A biometric method analyzing typing patterns for authentication (NIST).
Kill Chain – A model for the stages of a cyber attack (MITRE ATT&CK).
Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) – A catalog of vulnerabilities known to be exploited in the wild (CISA).
Lateral Movement – The technique of moving from one compromised system to another within a network (MITRE ATT&CK TA0008).
Layer 2 Tunneling Protocol (L2TP) – A tunneling protocol used with IPsec for VPNs (RFC 2661).
Layered Security – The use of multiple, overlapping controls to protect against threats (NIST).
Least Privilege – The principle that a user or process should have access only to what is required to perform its function (NIST SP 800-53).
Legal Hold – A process to preserve relevant data for litigation or investigation (FRCP).
Live Forensics – The collection and analysis of volatile data from a running system (NIST SP 800-86).
Live Response – Immediate actions taken during an incident to contain and mitigate damage (NIST SP 800-61).
Living Off the Land – Using legitimate tools and features on a system for malicious purposes (MITRE ATT&CK).
Load Balancing – Distributing network traffic across multiple servers to optimize performance (NIST).
Local Security Authority (LSA) – A Windows component handling authentication (Microsoft).
Logic Bomb – Malicious code that activates upon a specific trigger or condition (NIST).
Log Analysis – The examination of log files to identify security events (NIST SP 800-92).
Log Management – The process of collecting, storing, and disposing of log data (NIST SP 800-92).
Log Tampering – Altering or deleting log entries to conceal malicious activity (SANS).
Logging – The recording of events for later review and analysis (NIST SP 800-92).
Machine Learning – A subset of AI involving algorithms that learn from data (NIST).
MAC Address – A unique identifier assigned to network interfaces for communications (IEEE 802).
MAC Spoofing – Changing the MAC address to bypass network access controls (OWASP).
Malicious Code – Any code added, changed, or removed from a system to cause harm or subvert its intended function (NIST SP 800-83).
Malware – Software or firmware intentionally designed to perform malicious actions (NIST SP 800-83).
Malware Analysis – The process of determining the functionality and characteristics of malware (SANS).
Man-in-the-Browser (MITB) – Malware that infects a browser to intercept and modify web sessions (SANS).
Man-in-the-Middle (MITM) – An attack where the adversary relays and possibly alters communication between two parties (RFC 4949).
Mandatory Access Control (MAC) – A means of restricting access to objects based on the sensitivity of information and clearance of subjects (NIST SP 800-53).
Master Boot Record (MBR) – The first sector of a partitioned disk containing the partition table (NIST).
Mean Time Between Failures (MTBF) – A reliability metric indicating average time until a failure (NIST).
Mean Time to Repair (MTTR) – The average time to restore a system after failure (NIST).
Memory Forensics – The analysis of volatile data in RAM to identify malicious activity (Volatility Framework).
Memory Scraping – Extracting sensitive data from a process's memory space (MITRE ATT&CK).
Metadata – Data about data, such as timestamps or authorship, often embedded in files (NIST SP 800-86).
Metasploit – An open-source framework for developing and executing exploit code (Rapid7).
Mobile Device Management (MDM) – Software for controlling and securing mobile devices in an organization (NIST SP 800-124).
Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) – Authentication using two or more factors to verify identity (NIST SP 800-63B).
Nation-State Actor – An adversary sponsored by a government to conduct cyber operations (NIST).
Near Field Communication (NFC) – A set of communication protocols for short-range wireless exchange (ISO/IEC 14443).
Nessus – A vulnerability scanner used to identify security weaknesses (Tenable).
Netcat – A versatile networking tool for reading and writing data across network connections (Open Source).
Network Access Control (NAC) – Policies and tools to enforce security on devices connecting to a network (NIST SP 800-53).
Network Address Translation (NAT) – A method of remapping IP addresses between private and public networks (RFC 1631).
Network Forensics – The capture, recording, and analysis of network events to discover the source of security incidents (NIST SP 800-86).
Network Intrusion Detection System (NIDS) – An IDS monitoring network traffic for threats (NIST SP 800-94).
Network Segmentation – Dividing a network into subnetworks to limit breach scope (NIST SP 800-41).
Nmap – A free and open-source network mapper and port scanner (nmap.org).
Non-Repudiation – The assurance that the sender of information cannot deny having sent it (ISO/IEC 27000:2022).
OAuth – An open standard for token-based authentication and authorization (RFC 6749).
Open Source Intelligence (OSINT) – Intelligence collected from publicly available sources (SANS).
Open Web Application Security Project (OWASP) – A nonprofit foundation dedicated to improving software security (OWASP).
Operating System Fingerprinting – Identifying an OS from characteristics in network traffic (Nmap).
Packet Capture – The recording of data packets passing through a network interface (Wireshark).
Packet Sniffer – A tool for intercepting and logging network traffic (Wireshark).
Pass the Hash – A technique using stolen password hashes for authentication without the plaintext password (Microsoft).
Password Cracking – The process of recovering passwords from stored hashes (OWASP).
Password Spraying – An attack trying a single password against many accounts to avoid lockouts (OWASP).
Patch – A software update that fixes bugs or vulnerabilities (NIST SP 800-40).
Patch Management – The process of identifying, acquiring, installing, and verifying patches (NIST SP 800-40).
Penetration Testing – Authorized simulated attacks to identify vulnerabilities (NIST SP 800-115).
Pharming – Redirecting users from legitimate sites to fraudulent ones via DNS manipulation (OWASP).
Phishing – A social engineering attack to obtain sensitive information by masquerading as a trustworthy entity (NIST SP 800-63).
Physical Security – Measures to protect systems and data from physical threats (ISO/IEC 27002).
Personally Identifiable Information (PII) – Information that can identify or be used to identify a specific individual (NIST SP 800-122).
Polymorphic Malware – Malware that changes its code to evade signature-based detection (SANS).
Port – A logical endpoint for communication in TCP or UDP (RFC 793).
Port Scanning – The process of probing a network host for open ports (Nmap).
Post-Exploitation – Activities performed after initial access to maintain presence and achieve objectives (MITRE ATT&CK).
Pretexting – A social engineering tactic creating a fabricated scenario to obtain information (SANS).
Privilege Escalation – Gaining higher access rights than originally granted (MITRE ATT&CK TA0004).
Privileged Access Management (PAM) – Processes and tools for controlling privileged accounts (NIST SP 800-53).
Proof of Concept (PoC) – A demonstration that a vulnerability is exploitable (SANS).
Proxy Server – An intermediary server between a client and the internet for requests (RFC 2616).
Purple Team – A collaborative exercise between red and blue teams to improve detection and response (SANS).
Quarantine – Isolating infected systems to prevent spread (NIST SP 800-83).
Ransomware – Malware that encrypts files and demands payment for decryption (NIST).
Rainbow Table – A precomputed table for reversing cryptographic hash functions (Ophcrack).
RADIUS – Remote Authentication Dial-In User Service, an AAA protocol (RFC 2865).
Reconnaissance – The initial phase of gathering information about a target (MITRE ATT&CK TA0043).
Red Team – A group simulating attacks to test defenses (SANS).
Registry – A hierarchical database storing configuration settings in Windows (Microsoft).
Registry Forensics – Analysis of registry artifacts for evidence of user activity (NIST SP 800-86).
Remote Access Trojan (RAT) – Malware allowing remote control of a system (SANS).
Reverse Engineering – The process of disassembling software to understand its functionality (SANS).
Risk – The potential for loss of value to an organization from a threat exploiting a vulnerability (ISO/IEC 27005).
Risk Assessment – The overall process of risk identification, analysis, and evaluation (ISO/IEC 27005).
Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) – Access control based on roles assigned to users (NIST SP 800-53).
Rootkit – Software designed to hide the existence of malicious code (NIST).
Root Certificate – A self-signed certificate at the top of a certificate chain of trust (RFC 5280).
Rogue Access Point – An unauthorized wireless access point on a network (NIST).
Salting – Adding random data to passwords before hashing to prevent precomputed attacks (NIST SP 800-63B).
Sandbox – An isolated environment for running untrusted code safely (SANS).
Secure Boot – A process ensuring only trusted software boots the system (NIST SP 800-193).
Secure Shell (SSH) – A protocol for secure remote login and command execution (RFC 4251).
Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) – A deprecated protocol for secure web communications, replaced by TLS (NIST).
Security Assertion Markup Language (SAML) – An XML-based standard for exchanging authentication and authorization data (OASIS).
Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) – A system for collecting and analyzing security data in real-time (NIST SP 800-137).
Security Operations Center (SOC) – A centralized function for monitoring and responding to security events (SANS).
Automation and Response (SOAR)
column3: Security Orchestration, Automation and Response (SOAR) – Platforms automating incident response workflows (Gartner).

definition: Session Hijacking – Intercepting a legitimate session to gain unauthorized access (OWASP).
Shoulder Surfing – Observing someone entering credentials to steal them (OWASP).
Signature-Based Detection – Identifying threats by matching known patterns or signatures (NIST SP 800-83).
Smishing – Phishing attacks delivered via SMS (NIST).
Sniffing – Capturing and analyzing network traffic (Wireshark).
Social Engineering – Psychological manipulation to trick individuals into divulging confidential information (SANS).
Software-Defined Networking (SDN) – An approach to networking separating control plane from data plane (ONF).
Spear Phishing – Targeted phishing aimed at specific individuals (NIST).
Spoofing – Impersonation by falsifying data to appear as a trusted entity (RFC 4949).
SQL Injection – An attack injecting malicious SQL code into a query to manipulate a database (OWASP).
State-Sponsored Attack – Cyber operations conducted or funded by a government (NIST).
Static Analysis – Examination of code without execution to find vulnerabilities (SANS).
Steganography – The art of hiding information within other information (NIST).
Supply Chain Attack – Compromising a trusted vendor to infiltrate targets (NIST IR 8276).
Symmetric Encryption – Encryption using the same key for both encryption and decryption (NIST SP 800-57).
Syslog – A standard protocol for message logging (RFC 5424).
System Integrity – Protection against unauthorized modification of system components (NIST SP 800-53).
Techniques
column4: Tactics, Techniques, and Procedures (TTP) – The methods and behaviors used by adversaries (MITRE ATT&CK).

definition: Tailgating – Gaining physical access by following an authorized person (SANS).
Threat – A potential cause of an unwanted incident that may result in harm to a system or organization (ISO/IEC 27005).
Threat Actor – An individual or group that acts with malicious intent (MITRE).
Threat Hunting – Proactively searching for threats that have evaded detection (SANS).
Threat Intelligence – Knowledge about threats, including actors, campaigns, and vulnerabilities (NIST SP 800-150).
Threat Modeling – A structured approach to identifying and prioritizing threats (Microsoft SDL).
Time Stomping – Altering file timestamps to evade detection (SANS).
Token – A physical or electronic object used for authentication (NIST SP 800-63B).
Tokenization – Replacing sensitive data with non-sensitive substitutes (NIST SP 800-57).
Tor – The Onion Router, a network for anonymous communication (Tor Project).
Transport Layer Security (TLS) – A protocol providing secure communication over the internet (RFC 8446).
Trojan Horse – Malware disguised as legitimate software to trick users (NIST).
Two-Factor Authentication (2FA) – Authentication requiring two distinct factors (NIST SP 800-63B).
Virtual Private Network (VPN) – A secure tunnel for remote access over public networks (RFC 2764).
Virus – A self-replicating program that attaches to legitimate files (NIST).
Vishing – Voice phishing attacks over phone (NIST).
Vulnerability – A weakness in a system that could be exploited (ISO/IEC 27005).
Vulnerability Assessment – Systematic examination of systems to identify weaknesses (NIST SP 800-115).
Vulnerability Management – The process of identifying, evaluating, and addressing vulnerabilities (NIST SP 800-40).
Vulnerability Scanner – Automated tool for discovering known vulnerabilities (NIST SP 800-115).
Watering Hole Attack – Compromising websites frequented by targets to infect visitors (MITRE ATT&CK T1189).
Web Application Firewall (WAF) – A security device filtering HTTP traffic to block attacks (OWASP).
Whaling – Phishing targeting high-level executives (SANS).
Wi-Fi Protected Access (WPA) – A security protocol for wireless networks (IEEE 802.11i).
Wipe – Securely overwriting data to prevent recovery (NIST SP 800-88).
Wireless Intrusion Detection System (WIDS) – Monitoring wireless networks for threats (NIST).
Worm – Self-replicating malware that spreads independently (NIST).
Zero Day – A vulnerability exploited before a patch is available (NIST SP 800-53).
Zero Trust Architecture – A security model that assumes no trust and requires verification for every access request (NIST SP 800-207).
Zombie – A compromised device used in botnets for attacks (NIST).
Acceptable Use Policy (AUP) – A policy defining permitted and prohibited uses of organizational IT resources (ISO/IEC 27002).
Accountability – The property that enables activities or actions taken by an entity to be traced uniquely to that entity (ISO/IEC 27000:2022).
Active Directory Federation Services (ADFS) – Microsoft's implementation of federation services for single sign-on (Microsoft).
Advanced Encryption Standard-128 (AES-128) – AES with 128-bit key length for symmetric encryption (FIPS 197).
Advanced Persistent Threat Group – Organized adversaries with sustained access to networks for espionage or disruption (NIST SP 800-39).
Air Gap – Physical separation of a system from all networks to prevent data transfer (NIST SP 800-53).
Algorithm – A finite set of steps for solving a problem, used in cryptography for encryption/decryption (NIST SP 800-57).
Allowlisting – The practice of specifying an explicit list of programs, devices, or users allowed access (NIST SP 800-167).
Anomaly-Based Intrusion Detection – Detection using statistical models to identify deviations from normal behavior (NIST SP 800-94).
Anti-Virus (AV) – Software that detects and removes viruses and other malware (NIST SP 800-83).
Application Firewall – A firewall operating at the application layer to filter traffic based on application data (NIST SP 800-41).
Application Security Testing – Methods like SAST and DAST to identify vulnerabilities in software (OWASP).
Asset Inventory – A comprehensive list of all organizational assets, including hardware and software (ISO/IEC 27001).
Asymmetric Key Algorithm – Cryptographic algorithm using public/private key pairs, e.g., RSA (NIST SP 800-57).
Attack Vector – A path or means by which an attacker can gain access to a system (MITRE ATT&CK).
Audit – An independent review and examination of records and activities to assess compliance (ISO/IEC 27001).
Audit Review – The process of analyzing audit logs for security events (NIST SP 800-92).
Authentication Header (AH) – IPsec protocol providing integrity and authentication without confidentiality (RFC 4302).
Authentication Server – A server that verifies user identities during login (RFC 2865).
Authorization Server – Server issuing access tokens in OAuth (RFC 6749).
Automated Vulnerability Scanning – Use of tools to automatically identify known vulnerabilities (NIST SP 800-115).
Availability – The property of being accessible and usable upon demand by an authorized entity (ISO/IEC 27000:2022).
Backscatter – Unintended echo of network traffic, often used in DDoS amplification (NIST SP 800-61).
Baseline Security Posture – The minimum set of security controls required for an organization's systems (NIST SP 800-53).
Bastion – A hardened system exposed to the internet for limited services (NIST SP 800-41).
Behavioral Analytics – Use of machine learning to detect unusual user or system behavior (SANS).
Biba Model – Integrity model preventing information flow from low-integrity to high-integrity subjects (NIST IR 7298).
Biometrics – Automated recognition of individuals based on biological traits (NIST SP 800-76).
Bit-Splitting – Distributing bits of a key across multiple parties for secure storage (NIST SP 800-57).
Blacklisting – Denying access to known malicious entities (NIST SP 800-179).
Blockchain Forensics – Analysis of blockchain transactions for investigative purposes (SWGDE).
Block Cipher Mode – Method of applying block ciphers, e.g., CBC or GCM (NIST SP 800-38A).
Blue Teaming – Defensive exercises to improve incident response capabilities (SANS).
Boot Integrity – Ensuring the boot process loads only trusted code (NIST SP 800-193).
Bot Herder – Synonym for botmaster, controlling botnets (NIST SP 800-83).
Boundary Protection – Controls at network perimeters to prevent unauthorized entry (NIST SP 800-41).
Breach Notification – Requirement to inform affected parties of a data breach (GDPR).
Bring Your Own Cloud (BYOC) – Employees using personal cloud services for work (NIST SP 800-146).
Brute-Force Password Attack – Exhaustive trial of all possible passwords (NIST SP 800-63B).
Buffer Overflow Protection – Mitigations like ASLR to prevent exploitation (CWE-120).
Business Associate Agreement (BAA) – Contract for HIPAA compliance in third-party handling of PHI (HIPAA).
Business Impact Analysis (BIA) – Assessment of potential effects of disruptions to business operations (ISO/IEC 22301).
Business Process Reengineering – Redesigning processes to incorporate security (NIST SP 800-53).
Byte – Unit of digital information, typically 8 bits (NIST IR 7298).
Cache – Temporary storage for quick data access, vulnerable to poisoning (RFC 1035).
Capability Maturity Model (CMM) – Framework for process improvement in security (NIST).
Cardholder Data Environment (CDE) – Systems handling card data in PCI DSS (PCI SSC).
Carving Tool – Software for file carving in forensics, e.g., Scalpel (NIST SP 800-86).
Certificate Pinning – Associating a specific certificate with a host to prevent MITM (OWASP).
Certificate Transparency (CT) – Public log of certificates to detect mis-issuance (RFC 6962).
Chain of Evidence – Documentation maintaining evidence integrity from collection to court (SWGDE).
Change Control – Process to manage modifications to systems (NIST SP 800-53).
Change Management – Formal process for approving and implementing changes (ISO/IEC 27002).
Chief Privacy Officer (CPO) – Executive responsible for privacy compliance (NIST SP 800-122).
Cipher Block Chaining (CBC) – Block cipher mode linking blocks for security (NIST SP 800-38A).
Clark-Wilson Model – Integrity model for commercial systems (NIST IR 7298).
Clarke-Wilson Integrity Model – Model enforcing well-formed transactions (NIST).
Cloud Access Security Broker (CASB) Visibility – Monitoring cloud usage for threats (Gartner).
Cloud Computing – Delivery of computing services over the internet (NIST SP 800-145).
Cloud Service Provider (CSP) – Entity providing cloud services (NIST SP 800-146).
Code Review – Manual or automated examination of source code for vulnerabilities (OWASP).
Cold Site – Backup facility without pre-installed equipment (NIST SP 800-34).
Common Misuse Scoring System (CMSS) – Scoring for misuse cases in threat modeling (MITRE).
Common Vulnerability Enumeration (CVE) – Unique identifiers for vulnerabilities (MITRE).
Compliance Audit – Verification of adherence to standards and regulations (ISO/IEC 27001).
Computer Forensics – Subset of digital forensics focused on computers (NIST SP 800-86).
Confidential Computing – Protection of data in use through hardware enclaves (NIST).
Confidentiality Agreement – Legal contract protecting sensitive information (NIST SP 800-53).
Configuration Auditing – Verification that configurations match baselines (NIST SP 800-128).
Configuration Baseline – Approved configuration for systems (NIST SP 800-128).
Configuration Drift – Unintended changes to configurations over time (NIST SP 800-128).
Continuous Diagnostics and Mitigation (CDM) – Program for real-time asset management (DHS).
Continuous Integration/Continuous Deployment (CI/CD) – DevOps practices with security integration (OWASP).
Control – Measure to modify risk, e.g., technical or administrative (ISO/IEC 27000).
Cookie Poisoning – Manipulation of cookies to alter session data (OWASP).
Corporate Governance – Oversight of organizational management including security (ISO/IEC 27001).
Covert Storage Channel – Channel for unauthorized data storage (NIST SP 800-53).
Credential Guard – Windows feature isolating secrets from processes (Microsoft).
Credential Reset – Process to change compromised credentials (NIST SP 800-63B).
Critical Security Control – Essential practices from CIS Controls (CIS).
Cross-Domain Solution (CDS) – System transferring data between security domains (NIST SP 800-53).
Cryptographic Module – Hardware or software implementing crypto functions (FIPS 140-2).
Cryptographic Protocol – Protocol using cryptography for secure communication, e.g., TLS (RFC 8446).
Cryptoperiod – Time span during which a key is authorized for use (NIST SP 800-57).
Cyber Hygiene – Basic practices to maintain system security, like patching (NIST).
Cyber Insurance – Policy covering financial losses from cyber incidents (NIST IR 7621).
Cyber-Physical System (CPS) – Systems integrating computation and physical processes (NIST).
Cyber-Resilient – Ability to prepare for, respond to, and recover from cyber attacks (NIST SP 800-160).
Cybersecurity Framework (CSF) – NIST framework for managing cybersecurity risk (NIST CSF 2.0).
Data Aggregation – Combining data from multiple sources, potentially revealing sensitive info (NIST SP 800-122).
Data Anonymization – Irreversibly de-identifying data (NIST SP 800-122).
Data Controller – Entity determining purposes and means of processing personal data (GDPR).
Data Custodian – Entity responsible for storing and protecting data (NIST SP 800-53).
Data Diode – Device enforcing one-way data flow (NIST).
Data Encryption at Rest – Encrypting stored data (NIST SP 800-111).
Data Encryption in Transit – Encrypting data during transmission (NIST SP 800-52).
Data Leakage Prevention – Controls to prevent unauthorized data exfiltration (NIST SP 800-53).
Data Loss – Unintended destruction or corruption of data (NIST SP 800-53).
Data Masking – Obscuring sensitive data in non-production environments (NIST).
Data Minimization Principle – Collect only necessary data (GDPR).
Data Obfuscation – Making data unintelligible without affecting its structure (NIST).
Data Ownership – Assigning responsibility for data lifecycle (NIST SP 800-53).
Data Privacy – Rights of individuals over their personal data (NIST SP 800-122).
Data Processor – Entity processing data on behalf of controller (GDPR).
Data Protection Impact Assessment (DPIA) – Risk assessment for high-risk processing (GDPR).
Data Retention Policy – Rules for how long data is kept (NIST SP 800-53).
Data Sanitization Method – Techniques like overwriting or destruction (NIST SP 800-88).
Data Spillage Response – Procedures for handling unauthorized data exposure (NIST).
Data Steward – Role overseeing data quality and policy compliance (NIST).
Data Subject – Individual whose personal data is processed (GDPR).
Data Synchronization – Aligning data across systems (NIST SP 800-53).
Data Tokenization – Replacing sensitive data with tokens (NIST SP 800-57).
Data at Rest – Stored data, e.g., on disks (NIST SP 800-111).
Data in Motion – Data being transmitted (NIST SP 800-52).
Data in Use – Data being processed or accessed (NIST).
Data Warehouse Security – Controls for aggregated data stores (NIST).
Database Activity Monitoring (DAM) – Real-time monitoring of database access (NIST).
Database Encryption – Protecting data within databases (NIST SP 800-111).
Decentralized Finance (DeFi) – Blockchain-based financial services without intermediaries (NIST IR 8276).
Decoy Network – Honeynet for deception (NIST SP 800-83).
Decryption Key – Key used to decrypt ciphertext (NIST SP 800-57).
Defense-in-Depth Strategy – Multi-layered security approach (NIST SP 800-53).
Demilitarized Zone (DMZ) Configuration – Setup of DMZ for public services (NIST SP 800-41).
Denial-of-Service Resilience – Ability to maintain availability during attacks (NIST SP 800-61).
Deprecation Policy – Plan for phasing out outdated technologies (NIST).
Detection as Code – Treating detection rules as version-controlled code (SANS).
Developer Security – Secure coding practices (OWASP).
Device Fingerprinting – Identifying devices based on unique attributes (OWASP).
Dictionary Service – LDAP or similar for credential validation (RFC 4510).
Differential Analysis – Comparing data versions for changes (NIST SP 800-86).
Digital Certificate – Electronic document verifying identity (RFC 5280).
Digital Forensics Framework – Structured process for evidence handling (NIST SP 800-86).
Digital Identity – Electronic representation of a person's identity (NIST SP 800-63).
Digital Millennium Copyright Act (DMCA) – US law on digital rights (US).
Digital Rights – Legal protections for digital content (NIST).
Digital Signature Standard (DSS) – FIPS for digital signatures (FIPS 186).
Digital Watermark – Invisible mark for ownership proof (NIST).
Directory Harvest Attack – Probing for valid emails (OWASP).
Directory Service Security – Protecting LDAP/AD from attacks (NIST SP 800-123).
Disaster Recovery Testing – Simulating failures to validate DRP (NIST SP 800-34).
Discretionary Protection – User-controlled access (NIST SP 800-53).
Distributed Ledger – Blockchain or similar for shared records (NIST IR 8202).
DNS Cache Poisoning – Injecting false DNS records (RFC 1035).
DNS Reflection Attack – DDoS using DNS responses (US-CERT).
DNSSEC Validation – Verifying DNS responses with signatures (RFC 4033).
Domain Controller – Server managing domain authentication (Microsoft).
Domain Key Identified Mail (DKIM) – Email authentication with signatures (RFC 6376).
Domain-based Message Authentication – SPF, DKIM, DMARC for email (RFC 7208).
Drive-by Pharming – Redirecting via router compromise (OWASP).
Drive Imaging Tool – Software for forensic copies, e.g., dd (NIST SP 800-86).
Dual Control – Requiring two persons for sensitive operations (NIST SP 800-57).
Dump – Extraction of memory or file contents for analysis (NIST SP 800-86).
Dynamic Link Library (DLL) Hijacking – Exploiting DLL loading for code execution (MITRE ATT&CK T1574).
Dynamic Risk Assessment – Real-time evaluation of changing risks (ISO/IEC 27005).
EAL (Evaluation Assurance Level) – Rigorous testing level in Common Criteria (ISO/IEC 15408).
Eavesdropping Attack – Passive listening to communications (RFC 4949).
Edge Security – Protecting network edges like gateways (NIST).
Electronic Discovery Reference Model (EDRM) – Framework for e-discovery (FRCP).
Elliptic Curve Digital Signature Algorithm (ECDSA) – ECC-based signatures (FIPS 186).
Email Authentication – Protocols like SPF to verify senders (RFC 7208).
Embedded System Security – Protecting IoT and firmware (NIST IR 8228).
Encryption Key Management System (EKMS) – System for key lifecycle (NIST SP 800-57).
Endpoint Privilege Manager – Tool limiting admin rights (NIST SP 800-53).
Endpoint Protection Platform (EPP) – Integrated AV and firewall for endpoints (NIST).
Enterprise Mobility Management (EMM) – Managing mobile devices and apps (NIST SP 800-124).
Entity Authentication – Verifying the identity of entities (NIST SP 800-63).
Evidence Preservation – Maintaining integrity of digital evidence (NIST SP 800-86).
Exclusive Use – Sole access to a resource without sharing (NIST SP 800-53).
Exfiltration Tunnel – Covert channel for data theft (MITRE ATT&CK TA0010).
Extended Access List – ACL with detailed traffic matching (Cisco).
Failover – Automatic switch to backup system (NIST SP 800-34).
False Alarm – Alert without actual threat (NIST SP 800-94).
Federated Search – Querying multiple data sources as one (NIST).
Federation Services – Enabling trust across domains (SAML).
File Allocation – Assigning disk space to files (NIST SP 800-86).
File Carving Software – Tools extracting files from raw data (NIST SP 800-86).
File Header Analysis – Examining file signatures for type identification (SWGDE).
File Integrity Check – Verifying files against hashes (NIST SP 800-53).
Fileless Attack – Malware running without disk files (SANS).
File System Journaling – Logging changes to prevent corruption (NIST).
Firewall Rule – Policy defining allowed/blocked traffic (NIST SP 800-41).
Firmware Security – Protecting device firmware from tampering (NIST SP 800-193).
Forensic Acquisition – Creating verifiable copies of evidence (NIST SP 800-86).
Forensic Analysis – Detailed examination of evidence (NIST SP 800-86).
Forensic Imaging Tool – Software for bit-stream images (NIST SP 800-86).
Forensic Readiness – Preparing systems for investigations (NIST SP 800-86).
Forensic Soundness – Ensuring evidence admissibility (NIST SP 800-86).
Format String Vulnerability – Input flaws leading to memory corruption (CWE-134).
Forward Compatibility – New systems handling old data (NIST).
Full Disclosure – Public release of vulnerability details (OWASP).
Full Disk Encryption Key – Master key for FDE (NIST SP 800-111).
Functional Testing – Verifying system features work securely (NIST SP 800-115).
Fuzz Testing – Inputting malformed data to find crashes (OWASP).
Gateway Antivirus – Scanning traffic at network entry (NIST SP 800-83).
Generalized Audit Software – Tools for data extraction in audits (NIST).
Geolocation Spoofing – Faking location data (OWASP).
Global Platform – Standard for secure chip cards (GlobalPlatform).
Golden Image – Secure baseline VM template (NIST SP 800-125).
Governance Framework – Structure for security oversight (ISO/IEC 27001).
Grayware – Software with potentially unwanted behavior (NIST).
Group-Based Policy – Access based on user groups (NIST SP 800-53).
Guideline for Secure Use – Recommendations for technology use (ISO/IEC 27002).
Hardened Configuration – Secure system setup (NIST SP 800-123).
Hash Function – One-way mapping to fixed output (FIPS 180-4).
Hash Table Attack – Exploiting collisions in hashing (NIST).
Header Checksum – Integrity check for protocol headers (RFC 793).
Health Check – Monitoring system status (NIST).
